title: What's so great about Socrates? - Quora

response.answer_text: THIS MIGHT HELP U1) “understanding a question is half an answer”2) Education is the kindling of a flame, not the filling of a vessel.”3) “There is only one good, knowledge, and one evil, ignorance.”4) “I cannot teach anybody anything. I can only make them think”5) “Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a hard battle.”6) “Strong minds discuss ideas, average minds discuss events, weak minds discuss people.”7) “By all means marry; if you get a good wife, you’ll become happy; if you get a bad one, you’ll become a philosopher.”8) “He who is not contented with what he has, would not be contented with what he would like to have.”9) “If you don’t get what you want, you suffer; if you get what you don’t want, you suffer; even when you get exactly what you want, you still suffer because you can’t hold on to it forever. Your mind is your predicament. It wants to be free of change. Free of pain, free of the obligations of life and death. But change is law and no amount of pretending will alter that reality.”10) “Sometimes you put walls up not to keep people out, but to see who cares enough to break them down.”11) “Wonder is the beginning of wisdom.”12) “To find yourself, think for yourself.”13) ““The unexamined life is not worth living.”14) “Know thyself.”15) “Let him who would move the world first move himself.”16) “The secret of happiness, you see, is not found in seeking more, but in developing the capacity to enjoy less.”17) “The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new.”18) “I am not an Athenian or a Greek, but a citizen of the world.”19) “Prefer knowledge to wealth, for the one is transitory, the other perpetual.”20) “The mind is everything; what you think you become”21) “True wisdom comes to each of us when we realize how little we understand about life, ourselves, and the world around us”22) “He is richest who is content with the least, for content is the wealth of nature.”23) “To be is to do”24)"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.”

The Socratic Method is an essential way to analyze the validity of any person’s contention. Socrates laid out some important philosophical foundations. Here are some for practical usage. “The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.” This is arguably the most significant concept in all of philosophy. “Beware the barrenness of a busy life.” This tells you not to become wrapped up in a myriad of conceptual perceptions and banal acts but rather “be here now”.  “By all means, marry. If you get a good wife, you'll become happy; if you get a bad one, you'll become a philosopher.” That speaks for itself as a bit of humor. “Once made equal to man, woman becomes his superior.” This is Socrates’ recognition that females are the core of a sexual species and that males are peripheral females whose main purpose is to present half a seed.  “The way to gain a good reputation is to endeavor to be what you desire to appear.” “Be as you wish to seem.” Wish and desire are conceptual attributes and these quotes tell you that behavior counts, talk is cheap. “He is richest who is content with the least, for content is the wealth of nature.” Socrates recognizes that we were born with a survival instinct because we really want to be here and when we clutter this up with too many accoutrements, we lose the enjoyment of being here. We are better off not spending our time in the engagement of trivial pursuits. “I was really too honest a man to be a politician and live.” Unfortunately this speaks for itself. “He is a man of courage who does not run away, but remains at his post and fights against the enemy.” Belief causes courage and this says that if you really believe in something then stick to your guns. “Be slow to fall into friendship; but when thou art in, continue firm and constant.” This speaks for itself.  “Beauty is a short-lived tyranny.” This speaks for itself. “An honest man is always a child.” This says that honesty should only be given to those you respect because it can be so easily misused. “A system of morality which is based on relative emotional values is a mere illusion, a thoroughly vulgar conception which has nothing sound in it and nothing true.” Socrates knew that the concept of morality is made as a social lubricant and it cannot be created by arbitrary values.  “The poets are only the interpreters of the gods.” This is where Socrates explains that metaphysical analysis is ethereal. The Socratic Method, his assessment of knowledge, and the timing of his entrance makes Socrates the greatest contributor that philosophy has ever had.
